title: Council told to pay £4,850 after young girl misses more than a year of school
text:

A UK council has been ordered to pay a fine of almost £5,000 after a girl missed more than a year of school due to its failings.

An investigation was sparked into Leicester City Council after a primary school pupil failed to turn up for several months - during which time her mum said the authority failed to provide alternative provision.

The young girl failed to attend classes between March and June in 2017 and from September 2018 to May 2019.

The girl’s mum lodged a complaint with the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman (LGO) saying that the council failed to offer or identify "appropriate education" for her daughter who has autism and additional needs.

She also complained that the council failed to accept her daughter was not at school due to a medical condition - which resulted in her being wrongly referred to the children's missing education team.

The LGO investigator looked at claims that the council delayed issuing an Education Health and Care Plan (EHCP) and failed to provide school transport.

(Image: Photothek via Getty Images)

Complaints were also made about staff who "ignored emails and failed to permit phone contact".

The girl was due to start a new primary school which was named in her EHCP in September 2017.

Prior to that she had not been in school between March and June.

The placement was the subject of a tribunal which concluded in February 2018 and found a suitable school for the girl.

A plan was drawn up to transition the child back to full time school - and in the meantime the council began providing home education.

The council told the LGO that it expected the girl to be attending full time by September 2018 but it was highlighted that she was suffering ‘high levels of anxiety’ and her doctor said she was unable to attend school on medical grounds.

(Image: Getty Images)

But the investigator found that the council could have been providing education from September 2018.

"Once the council accepted a new school needed to be named, it should have looked to provide full time education. It is fault it did not," the report explained.

The Council accepted it delayed issuing an EHCP. It also accepted there was no evidence of schools having been consulted despite an officer stating they would be.

The fact that the girl's mum had to chase up the ECHP meant the LGO found the council to be at fault.

"Whether the girl was out of school due to a medical condition or not, the council had a duty to ensure she was able to benefit from education where it had the responsibility to do so. I have criticised it for not doing so," the investigator said.

The council told the LGO it would expect calls to the service to be responded to and would not expect its staff to ignore emails or fail to permit phone contact. The investigator also upheld this part of the complaint.

The LGO investigator concluded that the council was at fault for failing to offer or identify appropriate education for the child.

Their report recommended that the council makes a payment of £1,000 for missed education between March and June 2017 and a further payment of £3,250 for missed education between September 2018 and May 2019 to the girl’s school so that it can identify what support she needs to catch up on.

(Image: Getty)

The investigator also suggested the council pay £600 to the girl’s mum - £300 for time and trouble and £300 for distress.

The LGO said the council should now "amend its procedures so it keeps within statutory timescales for issuing EHCPs. It should inform me what changes it has made and how the issues affecting the EHCP in this case will be prevented in future for others."

A Leicestershire County Council spokesperson said: “We take complaints to the council or Ombudsman very seriously and regret that in this case that we did not identify appropriate education for the complainant’s child or issue an Education Health and Care Plan within the timescales.

"We have acted on the recommendation of the Ombudsman and have taken steps to ensure similar incidents do not arise."
description: The child's mum complained that the council failed to accept her daughter was not at school due to a medical condition - which resulted in her being wrongly referred to the children's missing education team
